Antikaon condensation in neutron stars

Subrata Pal11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}, Debades Bandyopadhyay22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} and Walter Greiner11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1} 11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}Institut für Theoretische Physik, J.W. Goethe-Universität, D-60054 Frankfurt am Main, Germany 22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}Saha Institute of Nuclear Physics, 1/AF Bidhannagar, Calcutta 700 064, India
Abstract

We investigate the condensation of charged K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson and neutral K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson in dense neutron star matter. Calculations are performed in relativistic mean field models in which both the baryon-baryon and (anti)kaon-baryon interactions are mediated by meson exchange. It is found that K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation is quite sensitive to the antikaon optical potential and depends more strongly on the nucleonic equation of state. For moderate values of antikaon potential and a rather stiff equation of state, a significant region of maximum mass star will contain K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson. The critical density of K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation is always higher than that of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation. With the appearance of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensates, pairs of p-K-𝑝superscript𝐾italic-p ADDOP:minus italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endp-K^{-} and n-K¯0𝑛superscript¯𝐾0italic-n ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn-\bar{K}^{0} are produced with equal proportion leading to a perfectly symmetric matter of nucleons and antikaons in neutron stars. Along with K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate, K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate makes the equation of state much softer resulting in smaller maximum mass stars compared to the case without any condensate.

I Introduction

The study of dense matter in laboratories reveals many new and interesting results. There is a growing interplay between the physics of dense matter and the physics of compact objects [1, 2]. The composition and structure of a neutron star primarily depends on the nature of strong interaction. The equation of state of neutron star matter encompasses a wide range of densities, from the density of iron nucleus at the star’s surface to several times the normal nuclear matter density encountered in the core. Since the chemical potentials of nucleons and leptons increase rapidly with density in the stars interior, several novel phases with large strangeness fraction may appear. Among these possibilities, hyperon formation is quite a robust mechanism. This is possible when the neutron chemical potential becomes sufficiently large so that the neutrons at their Fermi surfaces can decay into hyperons via weak strangeness non-conserving interactions. The threshold densities for hyperon formation strongly depend on the nuclear equation of state [3, 4].

In recent years considerable interest has grown in the study of the properties of kaons, K𝐾italic-KK, and antikaons, K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K}, in dense nuclear matter and in neutron star matter. Within a chiral S⁢U⁢(3)L×S⁢U⁢(3)R𝑆𝑈subscript3𝐿𝑆𝑈subscript3𝑅italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:endSU(3)_{L}\times SU(3)_{R} Lagrangian, it was demonstrated by Kaplan and Nelson [5] that a negatively charged antikaon K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} may undergo Bose-Einstein condensation in dense baryonic matter formed in heavy ion collisions. It was further predicted in the chiral perturbation theory that a K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensed phase may form in the core of neutron stars [6, 7, 8] in consonance with kaon-nucleon scattering data [9] and K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} atomic data [10]. In these chiral Lagrangians, the (anti)kaons are directly coupled to nucleons. The strongly attractive K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-}-nucleon interaction increases with density lowering the effective mass mK*superscriptsubscript𝑚𝐾italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endm_{K}^{*} of the antikaons. Consequently, the in-medium energy of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson, ωK-subscript𝜔superscript𝐾italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}}, decreases and s𝑠italic-ss-wave K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation sets in when ωK-subscript𝜔superscript𝐾italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}} equals to the K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} chemical potential μK-subscript𝜇superscript𝐾italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{K^{-}} which, in turn, is equal to the electron chemical potential μesubscript𝜇𝑒italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{e} for a cold catalyzed (neutrino-free) neutron star matter. The typical critical density for K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation in nucleons-only star matter is about (3-4)⁢n034subscript𝑛0OPEN:( NUMBER:3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(3-4)n_{0}, where n0subscript𝑛0italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{0} is the normal nuclear matter density. The exact value, however, depends on the model used, i.e. on the nucleonic equation of state and on the parameters employed, especially on the depth of the attractive K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} optical potential. The net effect of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation in neutron star matter is that K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} replaces electrons in maintaining charge neutrality and the energy of the condensate is lowered because of strongly attractive interactions between nucleons and K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} mesons. Due to the softening of the equation of state the masses of the stars are reduced in presence of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate [7, 11, 12, 13, 14]. It was also found that in presence of hyperons, K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation was delayed to higher density, and may not even exist in maximum mass stars. Protoneutron (newly born and neutrino rich) stars with K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate was shown to have maximum masses larger than those of cold catalyzed (old and neutrino free) stars - a reversal from ordinary nucleons-only star. These stars may undergo supernovae explosion and then could collapse to small mass black holes during deleptonization [15].

The situation for kaons is however quite different. Theoretical investigations based on Nambu-ADDOP:minus-Jona-Lasinio model [16], chiral perturbation theory [9], and one-boson-exchange model [12, 13] yield a repulsive optical potential for K+superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{+} in nuclear medium. Therefore, K+superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{+} condensation is expected to be forbidden in neutron stars.

In the traditional meson-exchange picture [17], (anti)kaons and baryons interact via the exchange of σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma, ω𝜔italic-omega\omega, and ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho mesons. In addition to the decrease of mK*superscriptsubscript𝑚𝐾italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endm_{K}^{*} with density here, the energy ωK-subscript𝜔superscript𝐾italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}} is lowered since K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson experiences attractive vector ω𝜔italic-omega\omega-meson potential due to G-parity of antikaons. In contrast, the isovector ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho-meson field is repulsive for K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and inhibits K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation delaying it to higher densities. In neutron stars at densities above normal nuclear matter values, most of the protons convert into neutrons by inverse β𝛽italic-beta\beta-decay since it is energetically favorable to posses a small number of electrons. The ratio of electrons to nucleons which is again equal to the proton fraction due to charge neutrality is typically Ye=Yp≈0.1-0.15subscript𝑌𝑒subscript𝑌𝑝0.10.15italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.15Y_{e}=Y_{p}\approx 0.1-0.15. Therefore, neutron star matter is highly asymmetric and quite distinct from ordinary symmetric nuclear matter. This suggests that the ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho-meson field should have a strong repulsive effect on K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson. On the other hand, the ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho-meson field induces an attractive field for K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson which is an isodoublet partner of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson. This should lower the effective energy of K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson, ωK¯0subscript𝜔superscript¯𝐾0italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{\bar{K}^{0}}, compared to that of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson thereby making K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson condensation more favorable in neutron star matter. The critical density for s𝑠italic-ss-wave neutral K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson condensation is governed by the condition ωK¯0=0subscript𝜔superscript¯𝐾00italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\omega_{\bar{K}^{0}}=0, and should depend sensitively on the equation of state (EOS). Using variational chain summation method with two-nucleon and three-nucleon interactions, Akmal et al. [18] recently predicted a neutral pion condensation phase transition in neutron star matter at a density of ∼0.2similar-toabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2\sim 0.2 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. So far no calculation of neutral K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation and its impact on the gross properties of neutron stars has been performed. In this paper, we investigate the effect of antikaon condensation with more emphasize on K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate on the constitution and structure of neutron star matter in the standard meson exchange model. For this purpose, we employ the usual relativistic mean field Lagrangian [17] for baryons interacting via meson exchanges and includes also the self-interaction of the mesons. The antikaons are treated in the same footing as the baryons which interact by the exchange of the same mesons. For the K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson, the Lagrangian density of Ref. [14] is used, and it is extended to include the K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson. We shall demonstrate within this model that, apart from the K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson (as already studied in Ref. [12, 13, 14]), the K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate may also exist inside a neutron star and has a significant influence on the star properties. We shall also show that the threshold densities for the antikaon condensates are quite sensitive to the poorly known high density regime of the equation of state.

The paper is organized as follows. In section II we describe the relativistic mean field (RMF) model of strong interactions. The relevant equations for neutron star matter with antikaon condensate are summarized in this model. In section III the parameters of the model are discussed and effects of antikaon condensates in neutron star matter are presented. Section IV is devoted to summary and conclusions.

II The Formalism

The starting point in the present approach is a relativistic field theoretical model of baryons and (anti)kaons interacting by the exchange of scalar σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma, isoscalar vector ω𝜔italic-omega\omega, and vector isovector ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho mesons. In the mean field approximation (MFA) adopted here, the meson fields are replaced by their mean values and the baryon currents by those generated in the presence of the mean meson fields. For a uniform and static matter within MFA, only the time-like components of the vector fields, and the isospin 3-component of ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho-meson field have non-vanishing values. For neutron star matter we need to include also the charge neutrality condition, which in presence of antikaon condensate is expressed as

(20)

In the present calculation we consider antikaon condensation as a second order phase transition. In principle in neutron star matter with two conserved charges, baryon and electric charge, the condensation can also be treated as a first order phase transition [14]. In this situation, the star would have at low density a normal phase of baryons and leptons followed by a mixed phase of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate and baryons, and possibly a pure K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensed phase at a higher density. However in the present situation this would be more complicated as K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} have to be treated as two separate phases, and especially when the threshold density of one condensate may be reached in the mixed phase of nucleons and the other condensate. Treatment of such a triple phase would be numerically very involved and is postponed to a future publication.

III Results and discussions

In the effective field theoretic approach adopted here, three distinct sets of coupling constants for nucleons, kaons, and hyperons associated with the exchange of σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma, ω𝜔italic-omega\omega, and ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho mesons are required. The nucleon-meson coupling constants generated by reproducing the nuclear matter saturation properties are taken from Glendenning and Moszkowski of Ref. [20]. This set is referred to as GM1 and listed in Table I.

Let us now determine the kaon-meson coupling constants. According to the quark and isospin counting rule, the vector coupling constants are given by

gω⁢K=13⁢gω⁢N  and  gρ⁢K=gρ⁢N.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑔𝜔𝐾13subscript𝑔𝜔𝑁andsubscript𝑔𝜌𝐾subscript𝑔𝜌𝑁italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-omega italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-omega italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end and italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-rho italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-rho italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.g_{\omega K}=\frac{1}{3}g_{\omega N}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}{\rm and}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}g_{% \rho K}=g_{\rho N}~{}. (21)

The scalar coupling constant is obtained from the real part of the K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} optical potential at normal nuclear matter density

UK¯⁢(n0)=-gσ⁢K⁢σ-gω⁢K⁢ω0.subscript𝑈¯𝐾subscript𝑛0subscript𝑔𝜎𝐾𝜎subscript𝑔𝜔𝐾subscript𝜔0italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-sigma ADDOP:minus italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-omega italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.U_{\bar{K}}\left(n_{0}\right)=-g_{\sigma K}\sigma-g_{\omega K}\omega_{0}~{}. (22)

The negative sign in the vector meson potential is due to G-parity. The critical density of K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} condensation should therefore strongly depend on the K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} optical potential. Recent fits [1, 21, 22] to the K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} atomic data indicate a strong attractive potential in dense matter. More recently, in high energy heavy ion collisions enhanced subthreshold K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} production with a steep spectral slope was found [23]. In a simplified model this may be interpreted as a strong K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} attraction in nuclear matter. On the other hand, available K-⁢Nsuperscript𝐾𝑁italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-NK^{-}N scattering length suggests a repulsive interaction. Recent analysis [22] of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} atomic data using a hybrid model which combines the relativistic mean field approach in the nuclear interior and a phenomenological density dependent potential at low density showed that the real part of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} optical potential could be as large as UK¯=-180±20subscript𝑈¯𝐾plus-or-minus18020italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:180 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:20U_{\bar{K}}=-180\pm 20 MeV at normal nuclear matter density while being slightly repulsive at low density in accordance with the low density theorem. Apart from the K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} optical potential depth, the critical densities for antikaon condensation depend sensitively on the nuclear equation of state at high density. The GM1 set is obtained from a Walecka-type Lagrangian with a self-interaction term for the scalar meson. Because of the linear density-dependence of the vector ω𝜔italic-omega\omega-meson field, it was found that the vector potential overestimates the relativistic Bruckner-Hartree-Fock (RBHF) results at high densities. Bodmer [34] first proposed an additional nonlinear ω𝜔italic-omega\omega-meson term in the RMF model of the form

ℒω4=14⁢g4⁢(ωμ⁢ωμ)2.subscriptℒsuperscript𝜔414subscript𝑔4superscriptsubscript𝜔𝜇superscript𝜔𝜇2caligraphic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.{\cal L}_{\omega^{4}}=\frac{1}{4}g_{4}\left(\omega_{\mu}\omega^{\mu}\right)^{2% }~{}. (28)

Later, it was found by Sugahara and Toki [35] that this modification led to a reasonable agreement with the RBHF results. The model parameters obtained [35] by fitting experimental data for binding energies and charge radii of heavy nuclei is referred to as TM1. The parameters of this set are given in Table I. We now briefly consider the case when hyperons are allowed in addition to nucleons. At higher densities when the Fermi energy of nucleons exceeds the effective mass of a hyperon minus its associated interaction, the conversion of nucleons to hyperon is energetically favorable. The hyperon-meson coupling constants are obtained as discussed before. Unless otherwise mentioned we use an attractive ΣΣSigma\Sigma well-depth of -3030ADDOP:minus NUMBER:30-30 MeV. With this choice the ΛΛLambda\Lambda and Σ-superscriptΣSigma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Sigma^{-} are the first two strange particles that appear at roughly the same density of 2⁢n02subscript𝑛0NUMBER:2 italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end2n_{0} in all the sets. More massive and positively charged particles than these appear at higher densities. Since the conversion of nucleons to hyperons relieves the Fermi pressure of nucleons, the equation of state is softened. The EOSs for star matter with only nucleons and hyperons are depicted by dash-dotted lines in Figs. 5 and 7 for the GM1 and TM1 sets. The maximum masses and the corresponding central densities are given in Table III. It is evident from the figures that the hyperons emerge at densities much earlier than the threshold density for K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} condensate even for UK¯⁢(n0)=-180subscript𝑈¯𝐾subscript𝑛0180italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:180U_{\bar{K}}(n_{0})=-180 MeV. Since we have seen that a soft EOS prevents K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} condensation, the hyperons therefore postpone K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} formation to higher densities. This effect is further accentuated because the negatively charged Σ-superscriptΣSigma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Sigma^{-} and Ξ-superscriptΞXi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Xi^{-} can replace electrons in maintaining charge neutrality. The standard mean field model used in the hyperon sector was found [39] to be inadequate to describe the strongly attractive hyperon-hyperon interaction observed in double ΛΛLambda\Lambda-hypernuclei. Since the core of a neutron star can be hyperon-rich [4], the hyperon-hyperon interaction is expected to be important. This may be accounted by considering two additional mesons, the scalar meson f0⁢(975)subscript𝑓0975italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:975 CLOSE:)f_{0}(975) (denoted by σ*superscript𝜎italic-sigma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sigma^{*} hereafter) and the vector meson ϕ⁢(1020)italic-ϕ1020italic-phi OPEN:( NUMBER:1020 CLOSE:)\phi(1020) which couple only to the hyperons (Y𝑌italic-YY) [13, 39]. In this paper, we have employed the relativistic mean field model where the nucleon-meson coupling constants are fitted to certain bulk properties at normal nuclear matter density. The model is then extended to high density regime to investigate the effects of antikaon condensation. The underlying assumption in the RMF models is that the meson field operators in the Euler-Lagrange equations are replaced by their mean values because the source terms in those equations increase with baryon density. Also, the coupling constants of the RMF models are density independent. There are other approaches where gross properties of dense matter relevant to neutron stars are calculated in the framework of nonrelativistic Brueckner-Hartree-Fock and variational chain summation (VCS) calculations using modern nucleon-nucleon interaction [18, 40, 41]. Recently, Akmal, Pandharipande and Ravenhall (APR) [18] have studied neutron star properties in the VCS method using a new Argonne V18subscript𝑉18italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:18 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{18} nucleon-nucleon interaction (which fit all the data of the Nijmegen data base) with relativistic boost corrections and a fitted three-nucleon interaction. This calculation represents at present perhaps the most sophisticated many-body approach to dense matter. The bulk properties obtained in the APR model are binding energy E/B=16𝐸𝐵16italic-E MULOP:divide italic-B RELOP:equals NUMBER:16E/B=16 MeV, nuclear symmetry energy aasy=33.94subscript𝑎asy33.94italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start asy POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:33.94a_{\rm asy}=33.94 MeV, and incompressibility K=266𝐾266italic-K RELOP:equals NUMBER:266K=266 MeV at a saturation density of n0=0.16subscript𝑛00.16italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.16n_{0}=0.16 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. To gauge the uncertainties involved in the extrapolation of the RMF model at high density, we compare the nucleons-only matter results with those of the APR model. For this purpose we use the model which contains nonlinear interaction for the scalar σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma-meson only. (Note that the TM1 model which includes also self-interaction of ω𝜔italic-omega\omega-meson is fitted to finite nuclear properties.) The five parameters in this RMF model are fitted to the above mentioned (four) saturation properties plus the effective nucleon mass of mN*/mN=0.70subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑁subscript𝑚𝑁0.70italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70m^{*}_{N}/m_{N}=0.70 and 0.78 for the two representative cases considered here. In Fig. 13 we show the results for pure neutron matter (PNM) and symmetric nuclear matter (SNM) in the RMF model (solid lines), and in the APR model with pion condensation (dashed lines) and their low density extrapolations without a pion condensed phase (dotted lines) [18]. It is clear from this figure that the agreement between the two models breaks down at high density. The APR model takes into account possibly all leading many-body correlation effects. It was also demonstrated [18, 40] that the strong tensor correlation gives rise to neutral pion condensation in PNM and SNM at densities of 0.20 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} and 0.32 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}, respectively. The RMF model, however, cannot address the question of density dependent correlation in dense matter, and moreover the coupling constants are density independent. This may be crucial to the deviation of the RMF results from the APR calculations. Consequently, the threshold densities of antikaon condensation may be affected. On the other hand, the advantage of the RMF models is that relativity is in-built and this causes the EOS to be causal. However, in the APR model the EOS becomes superluminal at densities close to the maximum masses of the stars.

We have computed nucleons-only star masses using this parameter set in the RMF model. For the case mN*/mN=0.70subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑁subscript𝑚𝑁0.70italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70m^{*}_{N}/m_{N}=0.70, the maximum masses of the neutron star matter (pure neutron matter) are Mmax=2.29subscript𝑀max2.29italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.29M_{\rm max}=2.29 (2.45)⁢M⊙2.45subscript𝑀direct-productOPEN:( NUMBER:2.45 CLOSE:) italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(2.45)M_{\odot} at central densities of ncent=0.92subscript𝑛cent0.92italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cent POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.92n_{\rm cent}=0.92 (0.80) fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. For the case mN*/mN=0.78subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑁subscript𝑚𝑁0.78italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.78m^{*}_{N}/m_{N}=0.78, the respective values are Mmax=2.00subscript𝑀max2.00italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.00M_{\rm max}=2.00 (2.20)⁢M⊙2.20subscript𝑀direct-productOPEN:( NUMBER:2.20 CLOSE:) italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(2.20)M_{\odot} at ncent=1.09subscript𝑛cent1.09italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start cent POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.09n_{\rm cent}=1.09 (0.91) fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. Comparing with the respective results of Mmax=2.20subscript𝑀max2.20italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.20M_{\rm max}=2.20 (2.21)⁢M⊙2.21subscript𝑀direct-productOPEN:( NUMBER:2.21 CLOSE:) italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(2.21)M_{\odot} in the APR model with pion condensation, we find that in the RMF model the maximum mass of a neutron star is more sensitive to the amount of proton fraction. It was shown [42] that a neutron star may cool rapidly by the so-called direct URCA process in which neutrinos generated in the stars interior carry away the energy. The threshold density for this process depends on the symmetry energy which in turn is determined by the proton fraction. For the APR model the threshold is at a density of nB=0.78subscript𝑛𝐵0.78italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.78n_{B}=0.78 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} corresponding to a star of mass ≈2.0⁢M⊙absent2.0subscript𝑀direct-productRELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:2.0 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\approx 2.0M_{\odot}. In the RMF model, for mN*/mN=0.70subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑁subscript𝑚𝑁0.70italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70m^{*}_{N}/m_{N}=0.70 and 0.78, the threshold densities are respectively, 0.59 and 0.61 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}, which correspond to neutron stars of masses 2.09 and 1.78⁢M⊙1.78subscript𝑀direct-productNUMBER:1.78 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1.78M_{\odot}. The relatively rapid rise of symmetry energy with density manifests in a smaller threshold density for the direct URCA process in the RMF models.

It may be worth mentioning that the role of nucleon-nucleon and kaon-nucleon correlations in kaon condensation in neutron star matter was studied by Pandharipande et al. [43]. The kaon energy for low density matter was calculated from Lenz potential while at high density the Hartree potential was used. The strong N⁢N𝑁𝑁italic-N italic-NNN and K⁢N𝐾𝑁italic-K italic-NKN correlations in the Hartree potential were shown to lead to a dramatic reduction of the antikaon attraction at high densities that could raise the threshold density for antikaon condensation to much higher values. Recently, kaon energy in neutron matter has been calculated analytically [44] by solving the Klein-Gordon equation in the Wigner-Seitz cell approximation. It was found that the transition from the low density Lenz potential to a high density Hartree potential occurs at ∼4⁢n0similar-toabsent4subscript𝑛0RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:4 italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim 4n_{0}. However, in a chiral perturbation theory, Waas et al. [45] found that short-range correlations has only a moderate effect on the antikaon condensation densities.

IV Summary and Conclusions

We have investigated antikaon, K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-}- and K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0}-meson, condensation in neutron stars within a relativistic mean field approach where the interaction between the baryons and antikaons are generated by the exchange of σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma, ω𝜔italic-omega\omega, and ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho mesons. Three different parameter sets (GM1, TM1, and GMT) have been exploited in this calculation. In the GM1 and GMT sets the Lagrangian contain self-interaction for σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma-meson only, while the set TM1 incorporates also nonlinear interaction for ω𝜔italic-omega\omega-meson. The softest nuclear equation of state follows from TM1 set whereas the stiffest one from GMT set. We find that the critical densities for K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and in particular K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensations depend sensitively on the choice of antikaon optical potential depth and more strongly on the nuclear equation of state. The threshold density of K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} always lie above that of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson. With the appearance of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensates, the overall equation of state becomes softer compared to the situation without antikaon condensation. This leads to a reduction in the maximum star masses. With the softest EOS (TM1 set), K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate may be formed inside maximum mass stars only when the K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} optical depth is quite large. On the other hand for the stiffest nuclear EOS (GMT set), K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} can occur well inside the maximum mass stars for rather small values of antikaon optical potential depth. The appearance of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson leads to a smaller variation of the vector fields with density. The decrease of K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} energy with density is therefore attenuated resulting in its formation at higher density than in the case when K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson is prohibited.

With the onset of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation (neglecting K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson), the proton fraction rises dramatically and even crosses the neutron fraction at some critical density. From the threshold conditions for K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} formations, i.e. ωK-=μn-μpsubscript𝜔superscript𝐾subscript𝜇𝑛subscript𝜇𝑝italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}}=\mu_{n}-\mu_{p} and ωK¯0=0subscript𝜔superscript¯𝐾00italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\omega_{\bar{K}^{0}}=0, it is evident that the critical point of identical proton and neutron densities (Fermi momenta) is precisely the density where K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} formation sets in. In earlier model studies of K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation only (where K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation were ignored), identical values of neutron and proton abundances were observed at high densities after K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation. It may therefore be instructive to revisit the antikaon condensation scenario including K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson in these models. With the onset of K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation, there is a competition in the formation of K--psuperscript𝐾𝑝italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-p{K^{-}}-p and K¯0-nsuperscript¯𝐾0𝑛OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\bar{K}^{0}}-n pairs resulting in a perfectly symmetric matter for nucleons and antikaons inside neutron stars. As the proton fraction is much enhanced in this situation, it may have profound implication on the cooling properties of neutron stars.

With the hyperon-meson couplings constants determined from hypernuclear data and S⁢U⁢(6)𝑆𝑈6italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:6 CLOSE:)SU(6) symmetry relation, the hyperons are formed earlier than antikaons. Since the EOS becomes softer, antikaon condensation can only occur at high densities. The negatively charged hyperons cause a larger reduction in the electron chemical potential compared to that of the isovector potential. This indicates that in contrast to nucleons only stars, K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} has a higher formation probability in hyperonic stars, but only for relatively larger values of K¯¯𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} optical potential depth.

For all the cases studied here, the maximum masses of the stars are found to be larger than the precise current observational lower limit of 1.44⁢M⊙1.44subscript𝑀direct-productNUMBER:1.44 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1.44M_{\odot} imposed by the larger mass of the binary pulsar PSR 1913 + 16 [46]. The recent discovery of high-frequency brightness oscillations in low-mass X-ray binaries provides a promising new avenue for determining masses and radii of neutron stars [47]. Large neutron star masses with an upper limit of M∼2.0-2.3⁢M⊙similar-to𝑀2.02.3subscript𝑀direct-productitalic-M RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2.0 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.3 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM\sim 2.0-2.3M_{\odot} have been extracted from kilohertz quasi-periodic-oscillations (QPO). The present investigation suggests that indeed both K-superscript𝐾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensates are possible in stars of such large masses. On the other hand, hyperon degrees of freedom which lower the maximum mass considerably, would be clearly excluded in these massive stars. In contrast, also very small masses of M≈1.35±0.04⁢M⊙𝑀plus-or-minus1.350.04subscript𝑀direct-productitalic-M RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.35 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.04 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM\approx 1.35\pm 0.04M_{\odot} have been accurately determined in binary pulsars [48]. It is clear that exotic degrees of freedom like antikaons and hyperons must occur in these pulsars at few times the normal nuclear matter density.

It has been inferred that large magnetic field ∼1018similar-toabsentsuperscript1018RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:18 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{18}G could exist at the core of neutron stars [49]. Though such large interior field is not accessible to direct observation, their existence could influence certain gross properties of neutron stars, such as cooling properties of the stars [50]. Recently, there has been a considerable debate about whether a charged Bose gas in a constant magnetic field could exhibit a Bose-Einstein condensation [51, 52, 53, 54]. Some calculations ruled out such a possibility [51, 52] whereas others predicted that it could occur in a magnetic field [53, 54]. The formation of a Bose-Einstein condensate of neutral Bose gas such as a system of K¯0superscript¯𝐾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} in a strong magnetic field may be an interesting possibility.
